title: Cold winter could see power prices double, Ian Marchant warns
text:

Sun, Oct 25, 2015, 00:14 BST - UK Markets closed Cold winter could see power prices double, Ian Marchant warns By Emily Gosden | Telegraph – 3 hours ago 183.02 -0.73 
Infinis chairman warns Britain's tight capacity margin could see 'very high spot prices that force commercial organisations to effectively ration demand' 
A prolonged cold snap could see electricity prices double this winter, forcing industries to ration their usage, the boss of one of the UK’s largest renewable energy firms has warned. 
Britain’s “very tight capacity margin” meant there is a “very realistic possibility” of power prices spiking if there is an unusually cold winter, said Ian Marchant, chairman of Infinis Energy (LSE: INFI.L - news ) . 
Mr Marchant was speaking after Infinis announced it was being taken private again by Guy Hands’ Terra Firma , after its share price halved due to a combination of Government policy reversals and the fall in electricity prices. 
Mr Marchant said the "bearish" outlook for oil and gas prices and the growth of renewables meant power prices were forecast to stay low for the next two years or so. 
But he said: "There's one thing that could push them up, which is the very tight capacity margin. And if we get a cold winter, we will see a spike in power prices." 
National Grid (LSE: NG.L - news ) last week confirmed that Britain faced the worst power crunch in a decade this winter as old coal power stations close. 
The spare capacity margin - the 'safety buffer' between peak demand and available supply was forecast to fall as low as 1.2pc before National Grid intervened with emergency measures to bolster it to 5.1pc - still the lowest since 2007-08. 
Mr Marchant, the former chief executive of 'Big Six' giant SSE (LSE: SSE.L - news ) , said: "We have not had a seasonally cold winter for the last four or five years, and that will be the real test. 
"If we have a normal winter we will be fine, it is if there is a sustained cold spell - that is when the system will get under stress. 
“I am not talking about the lights going out, I'm talking about very high spot prices that force commercial organisations to effectively ration demand.” 
Under one of its emergency schemes to cope with the tight margin, National Grid has already signed up a number of businesses who may be paid to switch off between 4pm and 8pm on winter weekdays . 
However Mr Marchant suggested a cold spell could still cause problems for other businesses. 
Once all available power plants were already running flat out, "the price has to go up sufficiently to stimulate people to reduce demand", he said, suggesting prices could “easily double”. 
Businesses confronted with high electricity prices might instead say “we are going to shut our factory two hours early”, he said. 
Some businesses could also see their energy companies cut off their supplies because they had signed up for “interruptible” contracts, where they pay a lower price usually in return for agreeing they may be cut off in a supply crunch. Mr Marchant said experience from when this happened in the last decade suggested affected businesses would still “howl with protest”. 
He said households should not see any short-term effect because big energy companies would have bought most of their electricity in advance but such spikes could feed through to increases of 5pc or 10pc in longer-term power prices. 
The Government and energy regulator Ofgem have also been keen to reassure consumers that the lights will stay on. 
But the warnings of rising prices echo comments made by former Ofgem chief Alastair Buchanan, who warned in 2013 that margins falling below 5pc in years to come would be "uncomfortably tight" and said: "We have to face the likelihood that avoiding power shortages will also carry a price."
